results.title: The Pagemaster
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Turner Pictures, David Kirschner, Paul Gertz, Joe Johnston and Pixote Hunt
results.brief_description: Richard is a shy boy but one day when he seeks refuge in a public library during a storm, he is suddenly transported into an incredible animated world filled with adventure and fantasy. In this world, anything is possible. The only limits are set by the imagination. Some of the greatest stories are made part of Richard’s life in the mystical world of “The Pagemaster.” Stars Macaulay Culkin as Richard Tyler, Christopher Lloyd as The Pagemaster, Ed Begley Jnr as Richard’s father and the voices of Whoopi Goldberg, Patrick Stewart, Frank Welker and Leonard Nimoy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Turner Pictures, David Kirschner, Paul Gertz, Joe Johnston and Pixote Hunt

results.title: The Pack of women
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Diana Manson and Ted Robinson
results.brief_description: The pack of women was first devised by Robyn Archer as a cabaret for the stage, and as such it played in London in 1981 and toured Australia in 1983/84. It involved three women and three musicians playing, speaking, dancing and singing - in turns serious, tender, witty, angry, outrageous, sombre, hilarious. All the songs, poetry and prose fitted together to make up a mosaic of new ways of looking at women. Old images were juxtaposed with new lyrics, layers of irony and humour bringing out startling new meanings in familiar songs, and new songs celebrating new women. This version is designed to be as enriching in terms of visual wit and density as it is in text, persuasion and performance.

results.brief_description: A history of the Pacific Ocean from earliest times. Animated diagrams, maps and charts are used to tell the story.

results.title: The Pace that thrills
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information and Frank Gardner
results.brief_description: A short review of some of Britain’s leading track athletes in action. Gordon Pirie, Mary Bignall Rand and Peter Radford demonstrate the correct methods of starting, sprinting, long-distance running and hurdling.

results.title: The Pace that kills
results.brief_description: Excessive speed is the number one killer on the roads: one-thrid of all road deaths are caused by it. By excessive speeding drivers risk their own lives and those of others.

results.title: The Oxyacetylene flame: master of metals
results.brief_description: Explains the principles of the oxyacetylene welding torch and illustrates the tuypes of work it will perfomr. Shows how acetylene is produced from carbide manufactured from limestone and coke and how this gas is burnt with oxygen manufactured from the air. The regulation of gases in the torch is explained and welding, brazing and cutting techniques are demonstrated. Contains animated segments to illustrate use of equipment.

results.title: The Owl who married a goose: an Eskimo legend
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Pierre Moretti and Caroline Leaf
results.brief_description: An Eskimo legend of a goose that captures the fancy of an owl. Although the voices are in Inuktitut Caroline Leaf’s innovative animation leave no doubt as to the happenings that transpire. It is a story with wry humour characteristic of many Inuit tales, for audiences young and old. Editing, Pierre Lemelin. (Eight awards, including Oscar nomination, Hollywood.)
results.title_for_label: The Owl who married a goose: an Eskimo legend

results.title: The Owl and the raven: an Eskimo legend
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Pierre Moretti and Co Hoedeman
results.brief_description: According to this Inuit legend the raven was not always the jet-black bird that it is today. The owl had something to do with it. What happened makes an engaging story acted out by two life-like puppets made of seal fur. The film, narrated partly in Inuktitut, partly in English, is largely the work of Inuit artists. Voice and narration by Toojatogak Itoacheak and Elatak Nakashook.

results.title: The Owl and the pussycat
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios and Morton Schindel
results.brief_description: A film of Barbara Cooney’s illustrations to Edward Lear’s poem. The owl and the pussycat travel in a pea-green boat to the land of Bong-tree where they are married by the turkey who lives on the hill. Photographed by Alexander Cochran. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: The Owl and the pussy-cat
results.creator_credit: Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films and John Halas
results.brief_description: Edward Lear’s nonsense poem tells the love story of the owl and the pussycat who sailed together to the land where the Bong-tree grows; there they married, ate wonderful food and danced by the light of the moon. This fantasy comes to life in Halas’ cartoon with the verses sung by Maurice Bevan. Animation: Vic Bevis, Reg Lodge. Suitable for lower primary school level.
